title: 111_hr3282
content: The program provides readjustment and mental health care services to veterans of Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a program to provide peer outreach, support, counseling, and mental health services to veterans of Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom, as well as their immediate family members. The program established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs provides peer outreach, support, counseling, and mental health services to veterans of Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom, as well as their immediate family members, to assist in their readjustment to civilian life. During the three-year period after a veteran's return from deployment in Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom, services are provided for readjustment to civilian life, recovery from injuries or illnesses, and family readjustment. Services include education, support, counseling, and mental health support. During the three-year period post-deployment, services are provided for veteran readjustment to civilian life, recovery from deployment-related injuries or illnesses, and family readjustment through contracts with community mental health centers and qualified entities. Entities for Provision of Services.--The Secretary will contract with community mental health centers and qualified entities to provide services in areas not adequately served by VA health care facilities. Contracts require employing veterans and using telehealth services when possible. The Department of Veterans Affairs contracts with community health centers to provide services, requiring them to employ veterans, use telehealth services, participate in training programs, and comply with VA protocols. The Department of Veterans Affairs requires community health centers to participate in training programs, comply with VA protocols, and submit annual reports on the veterans served and treatments provided. The Department of Veterans Affairs mandates community health centers to comply with training programs, follow VA protocols, and submit annual reports detailing the veterans served, diagnoses, and treatments provided. The Department of Veterans Affairs requires community health centers to provide clinical summary information for veterans receiving mental health services, along with meeting other specified requirements. The Department of Veterans Affairs contracts with qualified entities to provide mental health services for veterans and requires them to provide clinical summary information as specified. Additionally, the Secretary may impose other requirements. In addition, the Secretary is mandated to contract with a national not-for-profit mental health organization to train veterans for peer-outreach and peer-support services as part of the program. The Secretary will contract with a national not-for-profit mental health organization to train veterans for peer-support services. Additionally, clinicians at community mental health centers will undergo training to provide required services to veterans. The Secretary will conduct a training program for clinicians at community mental health centers to ensure they can provide services to veterans from Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom using best practices and technologies. Reports will be required. The Secretary will implement a training program for clinicians at community mental health centers to provide services to veterans from Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom, utilizing best practices and technologies. A report outlining the implementation plan must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 45 days of the Act's enactment outlining the plans for implementing the required program. Additionally, a status report is due one year after the Act's enactment. The Secretary is required to implement a program and submit a status report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year of the Act's enactment. The report should include information on the number of veterans who received services and the type of services provided in the last full calendar year before the report submission. The report on the program implementation must include the number of veterans receiving services, the types of services provided, an evaluation of service provision, and a recommendation on extending the service period. The report will evaluate the provision of services for veterans, including recommendations on extending service periods, listing national mental health organizations providing services, and assessing training programs.
